text: Anyone know why metamask might show a crazy high gas limit instead of telling me the tx would revert?
We just call that metamask jank

shouldn’t be $300 dollars for an erc20 approve. That would basically break all of defi. And other transactions are going through with expected gas limits. It’s an error in code execution but metamask is increasing gas limit instead of saying it will revert. Which it does
It was actually just an erc20 approve but transfers were not enabled so transaction would fail in any case

Has anyone experienced this—got a really high tx on a simple function that should have otherwise reverted but I didn’t realize that until looking back at the code. It was gonna cost like $300 but should have been more like $1 so I knew something was wrong

Also check out the Kernel page on getting started: <https://kernel.community/resources/smart-contracts/>

When you post a transaction a lot of clients do a simulation first. If you try to post a transaction that reverts in eg remix, you get a popup saying “this tx will probably fail, are you sure?”. If you say “yes” the tx will be posted, and will cost you gas up to the point of revert. If you say “no” then the tx is not posted and no gas cost.
So i was poking around flashloans and found an amazing tool <https://furucombo.app/>
This is great, but It doesn’t have simulation though. Have you tried executing one yet? :thinking_face:
$100 tx fees xD this ain't no time to mess around with ethereum
What do you mean by simulation? It tells you how much eth you'll get and different exchange rates
Lol yeah, on the gas prices

re: simulation

Combo — A -> B -> C

Result of this combo wont show the effect of A->B on the results. — its simply bundling the txs.

Has anyone here ever done a flash loan? I wonder if the loan hasn't been repaid then that means all token swaps with uniswap or curve etc would revert. But still since their contract methods were being called, you'd still have to pay the gas fees for all the stuff you did during the loan right? Like i am assuming $70-80 in fees for a unpaid loan/failed tx

<@U016PUP7D5Z>  If the tx reverts then I don't think gas will get spent because all such checks in audit contracts are there, though if it succeeds then you will have to pay for gas additionally ND right now gas prices are :rocket:

When you post a transaction a lot of clients do a simulation first. If you try to post a transaction that reverts in eg remix, you get a popup saying “this tx will probably fail, are you sure?”. If you say “yes” the tx will be posted, and will cost you gas up to the point of revert. If you say “no” then the tx is not posted and no gas cost.
This makes sense. Thanks <@U016Q31RVT5>
Be warned that there may also be assert checks in flash loans, which will eat all your gas.

1. Creator adds collateral, say 1 ETH, gets back arbitrary number of tokens, thus determining the start point on the curve?
2. People buy token thus invoking the mathematics, to determine what price they are buying at, they add to the collateral of the token, and in return get the token at the calculated price?

Hey everyone, sharing a tool I made to more easily make ERC-1155 NFTs on Rinkeby Opensea. Maybe someone will find it useful! <https://github.com/alto-io/contractor>
Hi <@U01733WAA1F> good job!  Can you provide some context?  Why would I want to create an ERC-1155 NFT...and why would I want to create one on Opensea?

Hey <@U0169D94QCX> thanks for the questions!

NFTs are non-fungible tokens, used to represent unique assets such as cryptokitties or nba topshot cards. ERC-1155 is one of the NFT standards.

Opensea (<http://opensea.io/>) is the largest exchange for these assets.

I needed to make my own NFTs over the weekend and was using Opensea's tutorials (<https://docs.opensea.io/docs/opensea-erc1155-tutorial>), and I saw that the process wasn't that simple. I made the contractor to make it doable in just a few steps :raised_hands:
What is the utility of these NFTs, are they mostly used in games?

yeah, ERC-1155s are usually for games, the format was created for blockchain games like Sandbox and Skyweaver. They're not exclusively used for that though, I think Rarible also supports the format for their collectible art
Interesting. This reminds me of Roblox
<https://www.roblox.com/games#/>
Roblox is great, wish we can get the developers there over on to web 3! :smile:

<!here> I'm trying to understand when to use different data locations in Solidity.  Does anybody know when to use the "memory" data location vs the "calldata" data location?  Is "calldata" only used in functions that are "external"?  Thanks!!!

Maybe you already read this thread, but just posting here in case you didn't.
<https://ethereum.stackexchange.com/questions/74442/when-should-i-use-calldata-and-when-should-i-use-memory>
<@U017F30AFRP> yeah I already read that, thanks Francis.  Just trying to crystalize my understanding of when to use calldata by asking the group :slightly_smiling_face:
The calldata option is a relatively recent addition. It saves on memory so I think the general principle is, if you can use it, you should use it.

Calldata vs memory 
Calldata used in external functions 
Memory used in public & internal functions 
Both are used with reference types ( strings , address, etc.)

Answering my own questions here but I found some really good resources today!

• Ready to go library contracts by Modular Network: <https://github.com/modular-network/ethereum-libraries#modular-libraries>
• Token libraries with proofs by SecBit: <https://github.com/sec-bit/tokenlibs-with-proofs>
• Smart contracts used in common defi protocols: <https://github.com/defiprime/defi-smart-contracts>
• TokenVesting implementation originally by OpenZeppelin: <https://github.com/akropolisio/akropolis-vesting/blob/master/contracts/openzeppelin/TokenVesting.sol>

<@U0169FVV2LF> highly recommend using your free pro account on tenderly to look into this further, given this part of their preso: <https://youtu.be/3BgevFiqnXE?t=867>

not shilling and have no personal interest, just seems like a particularly useful part of a well built product.
If you have some gas intensive parts of your contract, does that affect the gas on methods that aren’t gas intensive anyway?

No, unless this "non-gas-intensive" methods actually make calls to the "gas-intensive" methods. But if you don't have this internal calls between methods, you won't be charged for parts not used in your contract.

I'm not familiar w/ Tenderly (yet :slightly_smiling_face: ) suggested by <@U016Q117G67>, but it does looks really cool and a great tool. I'd give it a try for sure.

What I've used is a pluggin (`eth-gas-reporter`) for Truffle (if you're developing with truffle it may be an alternative) that checks the amount of gas used by each unit test.

It is useful to provide you an estimate of the amount of gas required for each method in your contract (as long as your tests really simulate the scenarios in which those methods will be called).

This is their npm package: <https://www.npmjs.com/package/eth-gas-reporter>
